### Explanatory Memorandum
### for Decree-Law No. 83 of 2025
### Regarding the Repeal of the Text of Article (29 bis)
### of Law No. 47 of 1993
### Concerning Housing Welfare <orig>الرعاية السكنية</orig>

Law No. 2 of 2015 was issued, adding the text of Article (29 bis) to Law No. 47 of 1993 concerning Housing Welfare <orig>الرعاية السكنية</orig>, with the aim of addressing the situations of categories who disposed of the residential units allocated to them under pressure from social changes in family circumstances, and their urgent need for more space or a change in the type of housing alternative, as

this Public Authority for Housing Welfare <orig>المؤسسة العامة للرعاية السكنية</orig> – and for one time only – refused to provide suitable housing for those who sold their homes and fully repaid the loan granted to them by the Kuwait Credit Bank <orig>بنك الائتمان الكويتي</orig>, by allocating suitable housing for them and their families according to their needs, whether as usufruct or rental. That article excluded the setting of controls, conditions, entitlement dates, and the prioritization of those addressed by its provisions to the competent Minister <orig>الوزير المختص</orig>, provided that this is done by a decision issued by him, while emphasizing that this allocation does not, in any way, affect the priorities or entitlements of those addressed by the provisions of the aforementioned Law No. 47 of 1993. This article specified the applicability of its ruling to those who sold their homes after 14/4/1992, the date of implementation of the provisions of Decree-Law No. 20 of 1992 concerning exemption from loans of the Savings and Credit Bank <orig>بنك التسليف والادخار</orig> and installments of government houses, until 15/2/2015, the date of its implementation.
Since the application of the text of the aforementioned Article (29 bis) has resulted in numerous negative consequences, in addition to contributing to the differentiation of housing welfare opportunities among segments of society by providing more than one entitlement opportunity for a specific segment of citizens, which contradicts the social objective of housing welfare and conflicts with the general directions of the State in consolidating the principles of justice and equality among all segments of society, especially in light of the accumulation of housing applications for citizens who have not previously received housing welfare, particularly since the text of this article is concerned only with providing housing as usufruct or rental for a special category of citizens who obtained a loan from the Credit Bank <orig>بنك الائتمان</orig> to build or purchase a dwelling and then disposed of it by sale and returned the loan amount to the Credit Bank <orig>بنك الائتمان</orig> in the period between 14/4/1992 and 15/2/2015, excluding those who disposed of it by sale after that date, or those who disposed of ready residential units allocated to them by the Public Authority for Housing Welfare <orig>المؤسسة العامة للرعاية السكنية</orig> during the same period.
Stemming from the State's keenness to apply the principle of justice among citizens, to achieve public interest, and to ensure the allocation of housing welfare resources to those entitled to them, and since the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws, therefore, the present draft decree-law was prepared, comprising two articles. The first article stipulated the repeal of the text of Article (29 bis) of the aforementioned Law No. 47 of 1993, in order to avoid the negative consequences and problems that resulted from the application of this text.
The second article obligated the Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers <orig>الوزراء</orig> – each within his jurisdiction – to implement it, and specified its effective date as the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>
## Decree-Law No. 83 of 2025
### Regarding the Repeal of the Text of Article (29 bis) of Law No. 47 of 1993 Concerning Housing Welfare <orig>الرعاية السكنية</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD.
- And Law No. 47 of 1993 concerning Housing Welfare <orig>الرعاية السكنية</orig>, and its amending laws,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of State for Housing Affairs <orig>وزير الدولة لشئون الإسكان</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
The text of Article (29 bis) of the aforementioned Law No. 47 of 1993 shall be repealed.

### Article Two
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers <orig>الوزراء</orig> – each within his jurisdiction – shall implement the provisions of this Decree-Law, and it shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into force from the date of its publication.

Amir of Kuwait <orig>أمير الكويت</orig>
Mishaal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig>
Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>

Minister of State for Housing Affairs <orig>وزير الدولة لشئون الإسكان</orig>
Abdul Latif Hamad Hamad Al-Mishari <orig>عبد اللطيف حمد حمد المشاري</orig>
Issued at Seif Palace <orig>قصر السيف</orig> on: 11 Muharram 1447 AH
Corresponding to: 6 July 2025 AD.

# Decree No. 123 of 2025
## Amending Decree No. 84 of 2024
## Regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations

*   Having reviewed the Constitution,
*   And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
*   And Decree No. 73 of 2024 regarding the formation of the Cabinet, and its amending decrees,
*   And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding ministerial substitutions and delegations, and its amending decrees,
*   And based on the submission of the Prime Minister,
*   And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One

The text of clauses (8, 9) of Article Two of the aforementioned Decree No. 84 of 2024, and its amendments, shall be replaced with the following text:
*   (8) - The Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research <orig>وزير التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي</orig> shall perform the duties of the Minister of Education <orig>وزير التربية</orig> during his absence. The Minister of Education <orig>وزير التربية</orig> shall perform the duties of the Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research <orig>وزير التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي</orig> during his absence.
*   (9) - The Minister of Awqaf and Islamic Affairs <orig>وزير الأوقاف والشئون الإسلامية</orig> shall perform the duties of the Minister of Justice <orig>وزير العدل</orig> during his absence. The Minister of Justice <orig>وزير العدل</orig> shall perform the duties of the Minister of Awqaf and Islamic Affairs <orig>وزير الأوقاف والشئون الإسلامية</orig> during his absence.

### Article Two

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs <orig>نائب رئيس مجلس الوزراء ووزير الدولة لشئون مجلس الوزراء</orig> shall perform the duties of both the Minister of Interior <orig>وزير الداخلية</orig> and the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig> during their simultaneous absence.

### Article Three

The Prime Minister and the Ministers – each within his respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree. Anything contrary to it shall be repealed. It shall be effective from the date of its issuance and shall be published in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Prime Minister
Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>

# Council of Ministers Resolution No. 828 of 2025
## Regarding the Withdrawal of Kuwaiti Citizenship Certificates
## From Certain Individuals

The Council of Ministers
*   Having reviewed the Constitution,
*   And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
*   And Article (21 bis "A") of Amiri Decree No. 15 of 1959 regarding the Kuwaiti Nationality Law, and its amending laws,
*   And based on the submission of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior <orig>النائب الأول لرئيس مجلس الوزراء ووزير الداخلية</orig>,

Has resolved

### Article One

The Kuwaiti citizenship certificate shall be withdrawn from those mentioned below, and Kuwaiti nationality shall be withdrawn from anyone who acquired it derivatively through the holder of that certificate:
1.  Farah Musa'ed Rabi' Issam Al-Ajmi <orig>فرح مساعد رابع عصام العجمي</orig>.
2.  Owaidha Manahi Ayed Shtran Al-Ajmi <orig>عويضه مناحي عايض شتران العجمي</orig>.
3.  Khalaf Rashid Khalaf Rashid Al-Harbi <orig>خلف راشد خلف راشد الحربي</orig>.
4.  Ali Rashid Khalaf Rashid Al-Harbi <orig>علي راشد خلف راشد الحربي</orig>.
5.  Dhaher Farhan Ghadhban Muhanna Al-Fadhli <orig>ظاهر فرحان غضبان مهنا الفضلي</orig>.
6.  Fahad Barakat Nahis Afdehim Al-Rashidi <orig>فهد بركات ناهس افديهم الرشيدي</orig>.
7.  Nasser Salem Hussein Abdul Hadi Abu Jah Al-Ajmi <orig>ناصر سالم حسين عبد الهادي أبوجه العجمي</orig>.

# The Constitutional Court
In the Name of His Highness the Amir of Kuwait
Sheikh Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>الشيخ مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>
## The Constitutional Court
At the public session held at the Court on 29 Dhu al-Hijjah 1446 AH
Corresponding to 25 June 2025 AD
Presided over by His Excellency Counselor / Adel Ali Al-Bahouh <orig>عدل علي البحوه</orig>, President of the Court
And with the membership of Their Excellencies Counselors / Saleh Khalifa Al-Murshed <orig>صالح خليفه المرشد</orig> and Abdul Rahman Al-Darmi <orig>عبد الرحمن الدارمي</orig>
And Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Al-Saif <orig>إبراهيم عبد الرحمن السيف</orig> and Waleed Ibrahim Al-Moajel <orig>وليد إبراهيم المعجل</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. / Mohammed Khalid Al-Hussein <orig>محمد خالد الحسين</orig>, Session Secretary
The following judgment was issued:
In the application registered in the Constitutional Court's register under No. (1) for the year
2024 "Petition for Reconsideration"
Regarding the consultative chamber's decision issued in direct appeal No. (10) for the year
2024
Filed by:
Waleed Rashid Ahmed Bu Rubai <orig>وليد راشد أحمد بو رباع</orig>
### The Facts
Whereas the gist of the facts – as evident from the documents – is that the applicant
(Waleed Rashid Ahmed Bu Rubai <orig>وليد راشد أحمد بو رباع</orig>) submitted on 29/10/2024 a letter to
this Court, an application by way of a petition for reconsideration and a request for a ruling
on what was overlooked by the consultative chamber's decision issued on 10/7/2024 in direct appeal
No. (10) of 2024, where the application was registered under No. (1) for the year
2024 "Petition for Reconsideration", concerning the judgment of unconstitutionality of Decree-Law No. (14) of 1977 regarding the grades and salaries of judges, public prosecution members, and the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, in what it included of legislative omission regarding the positions of Vice President and President of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, and alternatively, accepting the application in accordance with the text of Article (148) paragraph (d) of the Code of Civil Procedure <orig>قانون المرافعات</orig> as a petition for reconsideration of the aforementioned consultative chamber's decision and ruling on his requests, stating that the applicant claims that the aforementioned consultative chamber's decision was surrounded by several reasons necessitating its reconsideration, as it overlooked all grounds of appeal and relied on a reason not requested by him, related to the appropriateness of the legislation and the reasons that prompted the legislator to approve it in the form in which it was issued, despite the fact that the presented reasons relate to the absence of a legislative text. Thus, the decision was issued without addressing the real grounds of appeal, which he requests due to its issuance without reasons. Furthermore, its ruling on a reason not requested or presented by the appellant is a ground for a petition for reconsideration, and also leads to the fulfillment of the requirements for applying Article (126) of the Code of Civil Procedure <orig>قانون المرافعات</orig>, as each of the reasons presented by the appellant for unconstitutionality is, in essence, a substantive request for the unconstitutionality of the legislative omission concerning the matter in dispute, and is sufficient on its own to file a constitutional lawsuit. When the decision presented to it overlooked all of them and ruled the appeal inadmissible due to lack of seriousness, it becomes void for violating the law, the Constitution, and what the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> has ruled regarding legislative omission, which prompted him to submit his current application.

This Court considered the application in its session on 28/5/2025, as detailed in its minutes. The applicant appeared in person and insisted on his requests. A representative of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> appeared and submitted a memorandum requesting, in conclusion, a judgment of inadmissibility of the petition for reconsideration, and alternatively, its rejection. The Court decided to issue its judgment on the application in today's session.
### The Court
After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and after deliberation.
Whereas Article (126) of the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> stipulates that "If the Court omits to rule on some substantive requests, the interested party may summon his opponent to appear before it to consider and rule on this request, and this shall be within six months from the issuance of the final judgment." The basis for applying the provision of this Article – and as established by the jurisprudence of this Court – is that the Court must have, due to oversight or error, completely failed to rule on a substantive request presented to it, leaving the request pending and not explicitly or implicitly decided upon. Defenses submitted in support of a substantive request fall outside the scope of this matter.
Given this, and as is evident from the decision issued by this Court in its session on 10/7/2024 in Appeal No. (10) of 2024 "Direct Appeal – Consultation Chamber," it stated what the appellant requested in that appeal, namely that he had "challenged the grades and salaries of judges, members of the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>, and the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> regarding its omission of legislative regulation for the positions of Deputy Head and Head of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, arguing that the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig> mandated the regulation of all matters related to the judiciary, judges, members of the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>, and members of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> by a law issued by the legislative authority. However, the challenged law deliberately omitted to regulate the occupancy of the positions of Deputy Head and Head of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, thereby making the occupancy of these two positions purely a matter of authority

And whereas, regarding the applicant's request to consider his application as a petition for reconsideration of the aforementioned decision of the Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> for its omission of the grounds for appeal and for ruling on a ground he neither requested nor presented, which is the appropriateness of the legislation, and for its violation of the law, the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, and the Court's previous jurisprudence concerning legislative omission, which results in the nullity of that decision and necessitates its reconsideration, it is established – and as the jurisprudence of this Court has settled – that the judgments and decisions of the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> are final and not subject to appeal by any means of appeal, including a petition for reconsideration. Upon their issuance, the Court exhausts its jurisdiction, and absolute authority is established for them, which prevents their review, disputing them, or seeking their annulment. As long as the path of appeal against them has been barred, there is no way to claim their nullity, because the nullity of judgments only occurs if they contain a grave fundamental defect that would strip the judgment of its essential components and pillars, and cause it to lose its entity and character as a judicial judgment. Furthermore, the judgments and decisions of this Court cannot be attributed with grave error that would lead its judgment to nullity, unless its judicial character is negated.
Given the foregoing, and what the applicant stated in the grounds of his request regarding the nullity of the challenged Court decision for its omission of the grounds for appeal and for ruling on a ground he neither requested nor presented, and for its violation of the law, the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, and the Court's previous jurisprudence, is nothing more than an attempt to discredit that decision in what it concluded and an attempt to undermine it and re-discuss it after any review of it has become impossible. This cannot be claimed, delved into, or addressed. What the appellant stated in this regard amounts to an impermissible appeal against the judgment, seeking to re-engage in what the Court has already decided, and re-discussing what it ruled with the aim of undermining its judgment, denying its authority, and disputing it, which is an impermissible matter.
Consequently, based on the foregoing, the appellant's request to rule on what the Court omitted from requests or to reconsider its previous decision does not meet the requirements for its acceptance, which necessitates a judgment of inadmissibility of the request.
For these reasons,
absolute discretionary power for the administrative authority, despite their importance, which necessitates setting the necessary controls and restrictions for their occupation and dedicating a special system for them, contrary to the provisions for occupying public positions. This omission violated the principle of equality, as the legislator issued the Law Regulating the Judiciary <orig>قانون تنظيم القضاء</orig> including rules for occupying senior positions therein, while omitting this matter for the Department of Fatwa and Legislation / Idarat Al-Fatwa wal-Tashri' <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, despite the necessity of equal treatment between them in their various functional statuses, in violation of Articles (7), (8), (26), (29), (50), (133), (164), (170), and (175) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>." The aforementioned decision responded to the appellant's previously stated requests by citing in its reasons that "Decree-Law No. (14) of 1977 <orig>المرسوم بالقانون رقم (14) لسنة 1977</orig> concerning the grades and salaries of judges, public prosecution members, and the Department of Fatwa and Legislation <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> – the challenged law – included the regulation of grades and salaries of members of the Department of Fatwa and Legislation <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, to be in accordance with the schedule attached to the law, and stipulated that members of the Department <orig>الإدارة</orig> assume their positions directly, except for the lowest grades. It also stipulated that, for matters not specifically addressed in this law, the provisions of the Civil Public Service Law <orig>قانون الوظائف العامة المدنية</orig> shall apply to them, which was superseded by Decree-Law No. (15) of 1979 <orig>المرسوم بالقانون رقم (15) لسنة 1979</orig> concerning Civil Service <orig>الخدمة المدنية</orig> and the Civil Service System Decree <orig>مرسوم نظام الخدمة المدنية</orig> issued on 4/4/1979. Thus, the challenged law has not omitted a provision that ought to have been included therein. As for the argument regarding the importance of these positions and the necessity of establishing special rules for their regulation, similar to the Law Regulating the Judiciary <orig>قانون تنظيم القضاء</orig>, this Court does not exceed its judicial function, with its standards and controls, to the function of legislation, nor is it concerned with the legislative policy adopted by the legislator to regulate specific situations, which concludes that ruling on the judgment is impermissible. This clarifies that the aforementioned Court decision definitively ruled on the appellant's requests in that appeal, and responded to the grounds he presented in support of them, which are that the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig> obligated the legislator to arrange the positions of the Fatwa and Legislation Authority / Hay'at Al-Fatwa wal-Tashri' <orig>هيئة الفتوى والتشريع</orig>, including the two positions of Vice President of Fatwa and Legislation, and that the provisions of the judiciary and the legislation itself acknowledged the existence of this legislative omission, which violates the principle of equality and equal opportunities, and the Constitutional Court's <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> previous jurisprudence in a similar matter related to the State Audit Bureau / Diwan Al-Muhasaba <orig>ديوان المحاسبة</orig>, by which the decision denied the existence of any legislative omission in the challenged law. Consequently, there is no basis for those grounds, which are merely aspects supporting the appellant's request for the unconstitutionality of the challenged law, and thus the Court has not omitted to rule on any substantive request of the appellant in that appeal. It is self-evident that the legislator did not require, in the Court's decision – convened in the Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> – regarding the inadmissibility of the direct appeal due to its lack of seriousness, anything other than to issue

The Court ruled: The request is inadmissible.

The appeal challenges the constitutionality of Articles 1/112 and 1/150 of the Capital Markets Authority law, citing violations of principles of equality, justice, and the right to fair litigation."

</page_metadata>
<header>
6A
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1747, Seventy-First Year
Sunday, 18 Muharram 1447 AH - 13/7/2025 AD

Whereas the appellant challenged the constitutionality of Article (1/112) of Law No. (7) of 2010 regarding the Establishment of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> and the Regulation of Securities Activity, specifically concerning the provision in this article that considers judgments issued by the Capital Markets Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة استئناف أسواق المال</orig> as final judgments, which may not be challenged by any means of appeal, including petitions for reconsideration <orig>التماس إعادة النظر</orig> and cassation appeals <orig>الطعن بالتمييز</orig>. The appellant argued that the legislator, by virtue of this article, has undermined the principles of justice, equality, and the right to litigation stipulated in Articles (7), (8), (162), and (166) of the Constitution, as it introduced an unacceptable arbitrary criterion, thereby preventing appeals by way of petition for reconsideration or cassation, even if one of the conditions allowing appeal by either means was met, simply because the judgment was issued by the Capital Markets Chamber <orig>دائرة أسواق المال</orig> of the Court of Appeal. This thus deprived those against whom such judgments were rendered of their right to access fair justice, and established an unjustified distinction between them and those against whom other judgments were rendered, without this distinction being based on objective grounds, and withheld from them a means to rectify grave errors in those judgments that necessitate their correction through a petition for reconsideration or a cassation appeal. The appellant also challenged the constitutionality of Article (1/150) of the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, regarding its stipulation that a petition for reconsideration must be filed with the same court that issued the challenged judgment, in cases where the judgment ruled on something not requested by the litigants or more than what they requested, or if the judgment's rulings contradict each other. The appellant argued that this article violated the principle of equality and infringed upon the right to litigation and the right to a fair trial before a court whose judges had not previously considered the case or formed an opinion on it, in violation of Articles (7), (8), (29), (162), (163), (164), and (166) of the Constitution. The appellant added that she had a direct personal interest in filing the present appeal, having filed a petition for reconsideration against the judgment issued against her by the Capital Markets Chamber <orig>دائرة أسواق المال</orig> of the Court of Appeal, and also having filed a cassation appeal against the same judgment. She further stated that a ruling on the unconstitutionality of the aforementioned Articles (1/112) and (150) would open the way for her to appeal, whether by petition for reconsideration or cassation, so that their inadmissibility would not be ruled, and that the petition for reconsideration filed by her would be heard before a different chamber than the one that issued it and expressed its opinion on the dispute, which prompted her to file the present appeal.

It was established, in accordance with Article (Fourth bis) <orig>الرابعة مكرراً</orig> – added by virtue of Law No. (109) of 2014 to the Law on the Establishment of the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> No. (14) of 1973 – that although the legislator permitted any natural or legal person to file a direct appeal <orig>ادعاء مباشر</orig> before this Court, this article stipulates that the appeal must have a direct personal interest, without which the appeal is inadmissible. This means that the legislative text alleged to violate the Constitution must have caused harm to the appellant as a result of its application to them, or that the likelihood of harm is probable, such that a ruling on its unconstitutionality would remove this harm and achieve a benefit for them. Furthermore, the legislator required that the appeal be serious as an indispensable condition for its admissibility, and this Court may investigate this matter; if it finds the appeal to be frivolous, it shall decide – in the consultation chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> – to dismiss it.

It was established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the principle of equality before the law entails prohibiting arbitrary discrimination between persons in similar legal positions. It does not mean treating citizens with varying legal positions equally under the law. Nor does this principle oppose all forms of discrimination, as the legislator, by virtue of their discretionary power, may impose a difference in treatment when justified by acceptable objective reasons dictated by necessity and its exigencies, and by considerations and requirements of public interest, provided that this difference is linked to the purposes sought by the legislator from the legislative act issued by them. It is also established that the multiplicity of litigation levels <orig>تعدد درجات التقاضي</orig> is a legal guarantee that primarily falls within the discretionary power of the legislator, and that the legislator, in determining the procedural rules governing judicial disputes, is not bound by specific forms that extend to all disputes, even with

  "page_summary": "This page presents a court ruling from Al-Kuwait Al-Youm, detailing the justification for the specialized procedural framework of the Financial Markets Court established by Law No. 7 of 2010, and ultimately rejecting an appeal against its judgments, citing lack of serious grounds and direct personal interest for the appellant, leading to the confiscation of bail."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1747, Seventy-First Year
7A Sunday, 18 Muharram 1447 AH - 13/7/2025 AD
</header>

Given this, and since the legislator had issued Law No. (7) of 2010 regarding the establishment of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> and the regulation of securities activities, aiming to regulate securities activities with fairness, competitiveness, and transparency, to develop capital markets and diversify and develop their investment tools, to provide protection for those dealing in securities activities, and to work on limiting inappropriate, illegal, and unfair practices in this activity, the legislator in this law sought to establish a specialized judicial body for capital markets activities to facilitate the resolution of disputes arising from the application of its provisions. Thus, the "Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>" was established within the Court of First Instance <orig>المحكمة الكلية</orig>, consisting of criminal and non-criminal circuits. The criminal circuits are specialized in adjudicating criminal cases related to the crimes stipulated in this law, while the non-criminal circuits are specialized in adjudicating cases related to commercial, civil, and administrative disputes arising from the application of the provisions of that law and the regulations and bylaws pertaining to the securities market, as well as substantive enforcement disputes related to judgments issued by it, regardless of the value of these disputes. Furthermore, criminal and non-criminal circuits were established within the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig>, specialized in reviewing appeals against judgments issued by the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>, and its judgments in these appeals were made final and not subject to appeal by any means of appeal. This is due to the special nature of the disputes brought before it, which are essentially related to capital markets and securities activities, requiring the rapid stabilization of the legal positions associated with them. Thus, the legislator has exercised his discretionary power regarding the procedural regulation of the aforementioned disputes falling under the jurisdiction of the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>, by establishing a litigation system for litigants before it based on the type of dispute, and linking this procedural regulation of litigation in those disputes to the objectives he aimed for in this law, without prejudice, at the same time, to the fundamental guarantees of the right to litigation. This ensures that litigants in these disputes can present their defenses and pleas to their natural judge and grants them equal opportunities to appeal the judgment issued by the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig> before the appellate circuit of the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig>. It also provided for a fair resolution to litigation in this type of dispute, redressing infringements on claimed rights, based on objective principles that do not create discrimination among those addressed by them in their application. Therefore, the divergence imposed by the legislator between the procedural rules governing disputes before the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig> and the procedural rules governing other disputes is due to the differing facts of each, the situations they face, and the persons addressed by them, which implies a difference in the legal positions of litigants in each. Furthermore, this divergence is based on a substantive rule related to the nature of the disputes heard before the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>, making it justified and not arbitrary, and it is linked to the purposes the legislator sought in issuing this law. Moreover, it did not prejudice the fundamental guarantees of the right to litigation enshrined in the Constitution. Consequently, the claim that the challenged text, as previously stated, violates the principle of equality and undermines the right to litigation is not based on a sound premise, and thus the appeal against this article lacks seriousness.

In light of the foregoing, and since the Court has concluded, as previously stated, that the appeal against the unconstitutionality of Article (1/112) of Law No. (7) of 2010 lacks seriousness, it follows that an appeal by way of a petition for reconsideration <orig>التماس إعادة النظر</orig> against judgments issued by the Capital Markets Circuit of the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig> is inadmissible, given that the judgment issued by it is final and not subject to appeal by any means of appeal. The implication of this is that the appeal against Article (1/150) of the Code of Civil and Commercial Procedure <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, regarding its provision that a petition for reconsideration <orig>التماس إعادة النظر</orig> must be filed with the same court that issued the challenged judgment, has become moot and there is no direct personal interest in appealing it, after the path of petition for reconsideration <orig>التماس إعادة النظر</orig> before it has been closed. Since a legally recognized interest cannot be merely a theoretical interest, aiming solely at the abstract annulment of the challenged texts, but rather a direct benefit must accrue to the appellant from requesting their annulment, it is therefore appropriate to rule on the inadmissibility of the entire appeal and the forfeiture of the guarantee <orig>الكفالة</orig>.

Therefore,
The Court – in chambers <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> – decided to dismiss the appeal and forfeit the guarantee <orig>الكفالة</orig>.

In the Direct Appeal / Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>

Filed by:
The First Investment Company <orig>الشركة الأولى للاستثمار</orig>

## The Judgment

After reviewing the documents and deliberation.

Whereas the appellant challenged the unconstitutionality of Article (1/112) of Law No. (7) of 2010 <orig>القانون رقم (7) لسنة 2010</orig> concerning the establishment of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> and the regulation of securities activities, specifically regarding its provision that judgments issued by the Capital Markets Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة استئناف أسواق المال</orig> are final and may not be challenged by any means of appeal, including a petition for reconsideration <orig>التماس إعادة النظر</orig>. The appellant argued that, by virtue of this article, the legislator has undermined the principles of justice, equality, and the right to litigation <orig>الحق في التقاضي</orig> as stipulated in Articles (7), (8), (29), (162), (163), and (166) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>. This is because it deprives those against whom judgments are issued by the Capital Markets Chamber <orig>دائرة أسواق المال</orig> of the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig> of their right to challenge those judgments by petition for reconsideration if one of its conditions is met, despite allowing this for litigants in all cases issued by other chambers except the Capital Markets Chamber, which constitutes an unjustified discrimination between parties in similar legal positions. The appellant also challenged the unconstitutionality of Article (1/150) of the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, regarding its provision that a petition for reconsideration must be filed with the same court that issued the challenged judgment, in cases where the judgment ruled on something not requested by the litigants or more than what they requested. The appellant argued that this article violated the principle of equality <orig>مبدأ المساواة</orig> and infringed upon the right to litigation and the right to a fair trial <orig>الحق في المحاكمة المنصفة</orig> before a court whose judgments are characterized by justice, and which has not previously considered the case or formed an opinion on it, in violation of Articles (7), (162), (163), and (166) of the Constitution. The appellant added that it had a direct personal interest <orig>المصلحة الشخصية المباشرة</orig> in filing the present appeal, as it had filed a petition for reconsideration against a judgment issued against it by the Capital Markets Chamber of the Court of Appeal. The appellant further stated that a ruling on the unconstitutionality of the aforementioned Articles (1/112) and (1/150) would open the way for this appeal, preventing a ruling of inadmissibility, and would allow the petition for reconsideration filed by it to be heard before a different chamber than the one that issued the judgment and expressed its opinion on the dispute, which prompted it to file the present appeal.

It is established, in accordance with Article (Fourth bis) <orig>الرابعة مكرراً</orig> – added by virtue of Law No. (109) of 2014 <orig>القانون رقم (109) لسنة 2014</orig> to the Law on the Establishment of the Constitutional Court <orig>قانون إنشاء المحكمة الدستورية</orig> No. (14) of 1973 <orig>رقم (14) لسنة 1973</orig> – that while the legislator has permitted any natural or legal person to file a direct appeal <orig>طعناً بطريق الادعاء المباشر</orig> before this Court – against any law, decree-law, or regulation – the legislator explicitly stipulated in this article that the appeal must have a direct personal interest <orig>مصلحة شخصية مباشرة</orig>, without which the appeal is inadmissible. This means that the legislative text alleged to violate the Constitution must have caused harm to the appellant as a result of its application, or that the likelihood of harm is probable, such that a ruling of unconstitutionality would remove this harm and achieve a benefit for the appellant. Furthermore, the legislator required that the appeal be serious <orig>الجدية في الطعن</orig> as an indispensable condition for its acceptance. The Court has the discretion to investigate this matter, and if it finds the appeal to be non-serious, it shall decide – in the Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> – to dismiss it.

It is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the principle of equality before the law <orig>مبدأ المساواة أمام القانون</orig> entails prohibiting arbitrary discrimination between parties in similar legal positions. It does not mean treating citizens with varying legal statuses equally under the law. Nor does this principle oppose all forms of discrimination, as the legislator, by virtue of its discretionary power <orig>سلطته التقديرية</orig>, may impose different treatment when justified by acceptable objective reasons dictated by necessity and its requirements, and by considerations of public interest <orig>المصلحة العامة</orig> and its exigencies, provided that this difference is linked to the objectives the legislator seeks from the legislative act it issues. It is also established that the multiplicity of litigation degrees <orig>تعدد درجات التقاضي</orig> is a legal guarantee that falls primarily within the scope of the legislator's discretionary power, and that the legislator, in defining the procedural rules governing judicial litigation <orig>الخصومة القضائية</orig>, is not bound by specific forms that extend to all disputes, even with differing subject matters. This is because the procedural regulation of judicial litigation cannot reflect rigid, uniform patterns for its resolution framework. Rather, the legislator must always choose among different forms of this regulation, selecting what is appropriate for the characteristics of the disputes it concerns and their procedural requirements. Thus, the forms required for enforcing the right to litigation <orig>حق التقاضي</orig> vary, without prejudice to it.

Given the foregoing, and since the Court had concluded, as previously stated, that the appeal against the unconstitutionality of Article (1/112) of Law No. (7) of 2010, which was challenged, was not serious, then the appeal by way of a petition for reconsideration of judgments issued by the Capital Markets Circuit of the Court of Appeal is inadmissible. This is because the judgment issued by it is final and not subject to appeal by any means of appeal. The implication of this is that the challenge to Article (1/150) of the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, regarding its requirement to submit a petition for reconsideration to the same court that issued the judgment being reconsidered, has become moot, and the appellant lacks a direct personal interest in challenging it, having already utilized the petition for reconsideration before it. Since a legally recognized interest cannot be merely a theoretical interest aimed at abstractly nullifying the challenged texts, but rather a direct benefit must accrue to the appellant from requesting their annulment, it is therefore appropriate to rule the entire appeal inadmissible and to forfeit the guarantee.
Therefore,
the Court - in chambers - decided to dismiss the appeal and forfeit the guarantee.
with the fundamental guarantees enshrined in the Constitution, which represent a safeguard for the protection of rights of all kinds.
Given that, the legislator issued Law No. (7) of 2010 regarding the establishment of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> and the regulation of securities activities, aiming to regulate securities activities with fairness, competitiveness, and transparency, to develop capital markets and diversify and develop their investment tools, to provide protection for those dealing in securities activities, and to work on limiting inappropriate, illegal, and unfair practices in this activity. In this law, the legislator sought to establish a specialized judicial body for capital markets activities to facilitate the easy and smooth resolution of disputes arising from the application of its provisions. Thus, the "Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>" was established within the General Court, consisting of criminal circuits and non-criminal circuits. The criminal circuits are specialized in adjudicating criminal cases related to crimes stipulated in this law, and the non-criminal circuits are specialized in adjudicating commercial, civil, and administrative disputes arising from the application of the provisions of that law and the regulations and bylaws related to the stock market, as well as substantive enforcement disputes related to judgments issued by it, regardless of the value of these disputes. Furthermore, criminal and non-criminal circuits were established within the Court of Appeal, specialized in reviewing appeals against judgments issued by the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>, and their judgments in these appeals were made final and not subject to appeal by any means of appeal. This is due to the special nature of the disputes brought before them, which fundamentally relate to capital markets and securities activities and require the speedy stabilization of the legal positions associated with them. Thus, the legislator has exercised its discretionary power regarding the procedural regulation of the aforementioned disputes falling within the jurisdiction of the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig>, by establishing a litigation system for litigants before it based on the type of dispute, and linking this procedural regulation of litigation in those disputes to the objectives it aimed for in this law, without prejudice, at the same time, to the fundamental guarantees of the right to litigation. This ensures that litigants in these disputes can present their defenses and pleas to their natural judge, and enjoy equal opportunities to appeal the judgment issued by the Capital Markets Court <orig>محكمة أسواق المال</orig> before the appellate circuit of the Court of Appeal, and has provided an equitable solution for litigation in this type of dispute that redresses the infringement of the rights claimed therein, based on objective principles that do not establish in the field

Whereas the appellant challenged the unconstitutionality of Law No. (125) of 2023 regarding the Regulation of Real Estate Agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig>, arguing that the text in Article (2) of the Law, which states "It is not permissible under any circumstances for a real estate agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> to be irrevocable or uncancelable," constitutes an infringement on the right to ownership and freedom of disposition. This is because a real estate agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> falls within the elements of the agent's private property after the consideration is paid from their private funds. It also constitutes an infringement on the agent's right to perform the entrusted work, by preventing them from taking any legal dispositions over the property owned by their principal without referring to them after paying the price. Furthermore, it violated the principle of equality by prohibiting real estate agencies <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> alone from being irrevocable or uncancelable, unlike other types of agencies. Article (4) of the Law granted parties to irrevocable or uncancelable real estate agencies <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> valid at the time of the issuance of this Law a grace period of one year from the date of its enforcement to regularize their situations, which constitutes a retroactive application of the law to legal positions that were established and completed before its issuance. Thus, the Law, in these two articles, violated Articles (7), (16), (18), (22), (29), (41), (178), and (179) of the Constitution. The appellant had a direct personal interest in filing this challenge due to a real estate agency <orig>وكالة عقارية</orig> issued to him under No. (408) of 2019, which stipulated irrevocability or uncancelability, prompting him to file this challenge.
It was established, in accordance with Article (4 bis) – added by virtue of Law No. (109) of 2014 to the Law Establishing the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> No. (14) of 1973 – that while the legislator permitted any natural or legal person to file a direct claim/challenge before this Court against any law, decree-law, or regulation, the legislator explicitly required in the text of this article that the seriousness of the challenge must be met as an indispensable condition for its acceptance. This Court has the authority to investigate this matter, and if it finds the challenge to be unserious, it shall decide – in the consultation chamber – its non-acceptance.
It was also established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the legislator's authority in regulating rights is, in principle, a discretionary authority, unless the Constitution restricts it with specific controls that are considered boundaries that may not be breached or overstepped. The essence of this authority lies in weighing between different alternatives that compete for the regulation of a specific matter, and preferring among them what it deems most effective in achieving the legitimate interests it intended to protect. Such regulation, when carried out in realization of a public interest, and to remedy a legislative deficiency, while adhering to constitutional controls and limits, is deserving to be presumed constitutional.
Given this, and since the legislator issued Law No. (125) of 2023 regarding the Regulation of Real Estate Agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig>, aiming – as disclosed by the Explanatory Memorandum of the Law – to address the phenomenon of exploiting irrevocable or uncancelable agency contracts in real estate buying and selling operations. This exploitation was for the purpose of evading the payment of fees due to the state on real estate sale contracts, as well as the evasion by parties to the agency from registering the property in the real estate registry so that their rights to housing welfare are not forfeited. The Law was therefore enacted to set matters straight in a specific and clear manner, to remove ambiguity in interpretations and close off avenues for flawed applications, and to achieve the goal of preventing property owners from competing with those entitled to housing welfare. It defined a real estate agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> as the contract by which the principal appoints another person in his place to carry out a legal disposition transferring ownership of a property, the effects of which accrue to the benefit of the agent or a third party. It did not permit this real estate agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> to be irrevocable or uncancelable, and granted parties to irrevocable or uncancelable real estate agencies <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> valid at the time of the issuance of this Law a grace period of one year from the date of its enforcement

## Reasons
The facts of the lawsuit are summarized by the plaintiff's submission on his own behalf, regarding the law for the settlement of the situations of legal parties, which stipulates that if the aforementioned period expires without their situations being settled, the real estate agency shall be considered a repurchase agreement <orig>عقد بيع ثماني</orig>, without prejudice to the rights of good faith and the state.
This indicates that the challenged law <orig>القانون المطعون فيه</orig> allowed the parties to the real estate agency <orig>الوكالة العقارية</orig> to settle their situations in a manner that expresses their true will and what they intended by concluding this agency. It did not impose any restriction on the right of ownership <orig>حق الملكية</orig> itself, nor did it prevent anyone from disposing of their property as they deem fit. Rather, it considered the failure of the parties to the real estate agency to settle their situations within the granted period as evidence that the relationship between them is, in reality, a repurchase agreement and not merely an agency for selling real estate. Thus, the law does not involve an infringement of the right of ownership, a derogation from its essence, or an aggression against it. Furthermore, the law does not constitute an assault on the agent's right to perform the entrusted work, as the agent retains the right to dispose of the property as agreed upon in the agency contract, without any restriction thereon. Therefore, this assertion is an unwarranted intrusion of the right to work. As for the claim of violating the principle of equality <orig>مبدأ المساواة</orig>, it is unfounded due to the difference between real estate agencies and other types of agencies, owing to their exploitation in buying and selling real estate and evading their registration and the payment of fees due to the state. This necessitated the legislator <orig>المشرع</orig> to establish different provisions for them compared to other legal agencies. This differentiation is based on acceptable objective reasons dictated by necessity and its exigencies, and by considerations and requirements of public interest <orig>المصلحة العامة</orig>, and is linked to the purpose for which the challenged law was issued. Therefore, it is justified and does not violate the principle of equality. As for the claim of applying the law retroactively <orig>بأثر رجعي</orig>, it is incorrect, as it applies with immediate direct effect <orig>بأثر فوري مباشر</orig> to existing real estate agencies at the time of its issuance. Consequently, the present appeal lacks seriousness and should be declared inadmissible with the forfeiture of the guarantee <orig>الكفالة</orig>.

## Therefore
The Court – in chambers <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> – decided to declare the appeal <orig>الطعن</orig> inadmissible and to forfeit the guarantee <orig>الكفالة</orig>.

Advanced Projects Establishment for General Trading and Contracting <orig>مؤسسة المشاريع المتطورة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> and Advanced Projects Center for General Contracting and Buildings <orig>مركز المشاريع المتطورة للمقاولات العامة والمباني</orig> with request No. 82 / 2022 for bankruptcy declaration to the Bankruptcy Department, requesting the initiation of his bankruptcy proceedings, as he is indebted to the defendants by virtue of judicial rulings for an amount of 400,000 Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>.
On the basis that, in his personal capacity and as such, eight judgments were issued against him obliging him to pay 400,000 Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> to the defendants from the first to the fourteenth. And since he has become unable to pay the debt and does not possess any source of income, bank balances, or real estate, which resulted in the impossibility of paying the aforementioned debt subject of the claim, hence the lawsuit.
The court reviewed the application file and the procedures taken by the Bankruptcy Department, where it reviewed the report of the Bankruptcy Committee, which concluded that the committee was unable to prepare a report on the debtor and recommended the appointment of a trustee from the list of licensed auditors at the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig>, by virtue of which Mr. Nasser Khalaf Al-Enezi <orig>ناصر خلف العنزي</orig> was appointed as the bankruptcy trustee.
And since the bankruptcy trustee proposed the declaration of bankruptcy for the debtor-plaintiff, and since the bankruptcy judge concluded the proceedings by referring the application to the Bankruptcy Court to examine the subject of the application, based on which the case was referred to this circuit and registered under the number stated at its head.
And since the case was deliberated as recorded in the session minutes, at the session on 8/9/2024, the plaintiff appeared represented by a lawyer, and the fourteenth defendant also appeared represented by a lawyer, and the bankruptcy trustee appeared in person. The plaintiff's representative presented a memorandum of defense, which the court reviewed, requesting at its conclusion: Firstly, to accept the lawsuit formally. Secondly, to rule for the declaration of bankruptcy for him and for both (Advanced Projects Establishment for General Trading and Contracting <orig>مؤسسة المشاريع المتطورة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> and Advanced Projects Center for General Contracting and Buildings <orig>مركز المشاريع المتطورة للمقاولات العامة والمباني</orig>) against all the announced parties, and to determine the date of cessation of payment, and to appoint the esteemed Counselor, Head of the Circuit, as the bankruptcy judge, and to appoint a bankruptcy manager, and a provisional agent for the creditors, to receive the bankruptcy assets for their management, collection of rights, and payment of obligations, and to carry out publication. The bankruptcy manager shall declare the bankruptcy judgment in the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig> and publish its summary in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> within two weeks from its issuance date, and register that summary in the name of the creditors' group in the Real Estate Registry <orig>مكتب السجل العقاري</orig> within thirty days from the date of the judgment's issuance.
At the session on 22/10/2024, the plaintiff appeared with his lawyer and submitted a portfolio of documents, which the court reviewed. The bankruptcy trustee also appeared and submitted an unsegregated document and a portfolio of documents, the most important of which was a copy of a real estate certificate proving that Advanced Projects Center for General Contracting and Buildings <orig>مركز المشاريع المتطورة للمقاولات العامة والمباني</orig> does not own any real estate, as well as a real estate certificate in the plaintiff's name, proving that he owns 55% of a property in Al-Surra <orig>السرة</orig> area, and a copy of a "to whom it may concern" certificate issued by the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> stating that the plaintiff does not own any industrial plots in his personal capacity or as such. He also submitted a copy of a report on the plaintiff's bankruptcy, which the court reviewed, requesting at its conclusion the declaration of bankruptcy for the plaintiff in his personal capacity and as such. The plaintiff also appeared represented by his brother and submitted an unsegregated document, which was a copy of a settlement and waiver declaration for a case by Musa Yassin Al-Shammari <orig>موسى ياسين الشمري</orig>, acknowledging receipt of the value of check No. 678 drawn from the National Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت الوطني</orig>. The eighth defendant also appeared represented by a lawyer and submitted a portfolio of documents, which the court reviewed.
At the session on 26/11/2024, the bankruptcy trustee appeared and submitted a memorandum of defense, stating that the date of cessation of payment was 29/11/2024. He requested at its conclusion the approval of the bankruptcy declaration for: 1- Khalid Jaafar Qasim Mohammed Ali <orig>خالد جعفر قاسم محمد علي</orig>, 2- Advanced Projects Center for General Contracting and Buildings <orig>مركز المشاريع المتطورة للمقاولات العامة للمباني</orig>, 3- Advanced Projects Establishment for General Trading and Contracting <orig>مؤسسة المشاريع المتطورة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> - with request No. 85/2022 for bankruptcy declaration, and to set the date of the debtor's application submission, 29/11/2024, as a provisional date for cessation of payment, and for the Bankruptcy Department to declare this and add expenses and legal fees to the bankruptcy estate. He also submitted a portfolio of documents, which the court reviewed. The plaintiff appeared represented by an agent, and the eighth defendant appeared represented by an agent, and the case was reserved for judgment.
At the session on 24/12/2024, the court decided to reserve the case for judgment, but it returned it for pleadings to notify those parties who had not been notified of the referral decision.
At the session on 28/1/2024 and subsequent sessions, the plaintiff appeared with his agent, lawyer, and brother, insisting on his requests. The bankruptcy trustee also appeared, as did the eighth and thirteenth defendants, and the latter submitted a portfolio of documents, which the court reviewed.
The court therefore decided to issue its judgment at today's session.
And regarding the subject of the lawsuit and the plaintiff's requests therein, it is established by the text of Article 1 of Bankruptcy Law No. 1 of 2020 <orig>قانون الإفلاس رقم 1 لسنة 2020</orig>, which stipulates that, for the purpose of applying the provisions of this law, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning assigned to each of them: Financial insolvency: when the debtor's funds are insufficient to pay his debts.
Article 2 of the same law stipulates that "The provisions of this law shall apply to:
1- Every natural person proven to be a merchant. 2- Kuwaiti companies."
<page_end>12</page_end>

.... its sole prerogative, provided that such assessment is reasonable and does not deviate from what is established in the case documents.....
(Appeals No. 555/2005 Commercial, Session of 8 / 10 / 2006)
Based on the foregoing and guided by it, and since the plaintiff's aim in his lawsuit was to declare his bankruptcy for himself and in his capacity as the owner of Advanced Projects Establishment for General Trading and Contracting <orig>مؤسسة المشاريع المتطورة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> and Advanced Projects Center for General Contracting and Buildings <orig>مركز المشاريع المتطورة للمقاولات العامة والمباني</orig> due to his cessation of payments and a financial deficit resulting from final judicial judgments against him and his inability to pay, and since it is legally established for declaring a debtor's bankruptcy that several conditions must be met: proving his status as a merchant, his cessation of payments due to a deficit in his financial position, and that his business is not sustainable. Upon the court's review of the case documents and the request submitted to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> and the procedures undertaken, these conditions were found to apply to the plaintiff for himself and in his capacity, especially since the appointed bankruptcy trustee <orig>أمين التفليسة</orig> concluded his opinion by approving his bankruptcy declaration and considering 29/11/2022 as the date of cessation of payments. Given this, and as previously stated, it was established to the court that all necessary conditions for declaring the plaintiff's bankruptcy were met, supported by the opinion of the appointed bankruptcy trustee <orig>أمين التفليسة</orig> due to his financial deficit. Therefore, the court finds the procedures undertaken by the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> and its judge <orig>قاضيها</orig> in handling the present request to be valid. Consequently, the plaintiff's request to declare his bankruptcy for himself and in his capacity is based on a sound factual and legal basis, and the court rules to declare his bankruptcy as will be stated in the operative part of the judgment <orig>المنطوق</orig>.
Regarding the expenses, including legal fees, the court obliges the plaintiff to bear them in accordance with Article 1/119 of the Code of Civil Procedure <orig>قانون المرافعات</orig> and Article 23 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>.
(For these reasons)
The Court ruled:
To declare the bankruptcy of the plaintiff / Khalid Jaafar Qasim Mohammed Ali <orig>خالد جعفر قاسم محمد علي</orig> for himself and in his capacity as the owner of Advanced Projects Establishment for General Trading and Contracting <orig>مؤسسة المشاريع المتطورة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> and Advanced Projects Center for General Contracting and Buildings <orig>مركز المشاريع المتطورة للمقاولات العامة والمباني</orig>, and to set 29/11/2022 as the provisional date for cessation of payments. The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall register this judgment in the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig> and publish a summary thereof in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> according to the procedures followed in this regard, and add the expenses and an amount of ten dinars for legal fees to be borne by the bankruptcy estate.

..... Article (29) thereof stipulates that the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall decide on the request within ten days from the date of the specified periods for responding to it, by issuing a decision to initiate preventive settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig>, restructuring <orig>إعادة الهيكلة</orig>, or bankruptcy declaration procedures, and shall specify in his decision a provisional date for cessation of payments. If his decision to initiate procedures does not specify the date on which the debtor ceased payments, the date of issuance of the decision to initiate procedures shall be considered the provisional date for cessation of payments. If the decision to initiate procedures is issued after the debtor's death or after his retirement from trade and the date of cessation of payments is not specified, the date of death or retirement from trade shall be considered the provisional date for cessation of payments. Article (33) stipulates that the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall, within ten days from the date of issuance of the bankruptcy judge's <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> decision to initiate procedures, reject them, or deem them inadmissible, publish and announce the decision and notify the concerned parties thereof ..... Article (34) stipulates that if the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> decides to accept the initiation of restructuring <orig>إعادة الهيكلة</orig> or bankruptcy declaration procedures, he shall, in the same decision, appoint the trustee nominated by the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> and determine his fees in accordance with the provisions of this law ..... Article (49) stipulates that the trustee shall collect his fees specified in his appointment decision and the necessary expenses he incurs from the debtor's known funds for the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, and a payment of those fees and expenses on account may be disbursed by a decision of the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>.
Article 131 of the same law stipulates that "...... the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall issue his decision to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures if the following conditions are met: 1 - The debtor has ceased payments – 2 – There is a deficit in the debtor's financial position – 3 – The debtor's business is not sustainable."
Article 132 of the same law stipulates that "In all cases where the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issues his decision to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures, the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall refer the file of the request to initiate bankruptcy procedures to the Bankruptcy Court <orig>محكمة الإفلاس</orig> within ten days from the date of issuance of the bankruptcy judge's <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> decision to initiate bankruptcy declaration procedures. A report on the procedures taken for the request from its submission until the issuance of the decision to initiate procedures shall be deposited in the file, along with a statement of the factual and legal grounds for the decision." It was established in the jurisprudence of the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> that anyone who engages in commercial transactions in his own name and adopts them as his profession is a merchant, and that any creditor with a due commercial debt may request the bankruptcy declaration of his merchant debtor if the merchant's business is disturbed and he ceases to pay his debt in a manner that indicates a disturbed financial position and a severe predicament that shakes the merchant's credit, thereby endangering the rights of his creditors, and that the inference of whether a person is a merchant or not, and the inference of the facts constituting the state of cessation of payments that lead to the declaration of a merchant's bankruptcy, are matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the trial court, provided that it provides reasonable grounds for such.
(Appeal No. 159/1995 Commercial, Session of 30 / 6 / 1996)
It was established, and as the jurisprudence of the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> has held, that the trial court has full authority to examine the evidence and documents submitted to it, to weigh what it deems more credible among them, to deduce what it believes to be the reality of the case, and to assess its sufficiency for conviction from

Has decided
### Article One
Judicial enforcement status shall be granted, with respect to crimes and violations arising from the application of the laws specified in the preamble of this decision, to the employees listed in the attached roster for a period of (one year).

### Article Two
The employees assigned in the attached roster, each within the scope of the department they belong to, shall, in the performance of their duties, apprehend and prove crimes committed in violation of the provisions specified in the preamble of this decision, and prepare the necessary reports. They shall have the right to inspect shops and enter all places not designated for residence to apprehend violations, and they may, in the performance of their duties, request assistance from police officers.

### Article Three
All responsible parties, each within their respective jurisdiction, shall implement this decision. It shall be effective from the date of its issuance, and anything contrary to its provisions shall be repealed. It shall be published in the Official Gazette.

# Ministerial Decision No. (131) of 2025
## Regarding the Repeal of Ministerial Decision No. (188) of 2020
## Concerning Training Courses for Entities Subject to the Supervision of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig> in Implementation of the Requirements of Law No. (106) of 2013 on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

The Minister of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزير التجارة والصناعة</orig>:
Having reviewed:
- Law No. (106) of 2013 on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, as amended by Law No. 24 of 2016 AD,
- And Decree No. (191) of 2015 AD regarding the Organization of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>,
- And Decree No. 73 of 2024 on the Formation of the Ministry <orig>الوزارة</orig> and its amending decrees,
- And Ministerial Decision No. 37 of 2013 issuing the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> for Law No. 106 of 2013 on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, and its amending Ministerial Decisions,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (409) of 2013 regarding the Controls and Instructions Regulating the Operations of Exchange Institutions and Companies <orig>مؤسسات وشركات الصرافة</orig>,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (412) of 2013 regarding the Controls and Instructions Regulating the Operations of Insurance Companies <orig>شركات التأمين</orig>, their Agents, and Brokers,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (430) of 2016 regarding the Controls Regulating the Operations of Institutions and Companies Engaged in Real Estate Practice <orig>ممارسة العقار</orig> and Real Estate Offices <orig>المكاتب العقارية</orig> pertaining to Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (431) of 2016 regarding the Controls Regulating the Operations of Institutions and Companies Working in the Field of Gold, Precious Stones, and Precious Metals Trade <orig>تجارة الذهب والأحجار الكريمة والمعادن الثمينة</orig> pertaining to Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (188) of 2020 regarding Training Courses for Entities Subject to the Supervision of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig> in Implementation of the Requirements of Law No. (106) of 2013 on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing,
- And Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> Decision No. (8) of 2025 regarding the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of the Special Committee for Implementing Security Council Resolutions Issued under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter Pertaining to Combating Terrorism and the Financing of the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction,
- And based on what was presented by the Undersecretary of the Ministry <orig>وكيل الوزارة</orig>,
- And based on the exigencies of public interest <orig>المصلحة العامة</orig>,
- And pursuant to the powers vested in us.

Resolves

### Article One
Ministerial Decision No. 188 of 2020, referred to above, shall be repealed as of the date of issuance of this Decision. Furthermore, any text or provision that contradicts the provisions of this Decision shall be repealed.

### Article Two
Officials – each within their jurisdiction – shall implement this Decision. It shall be effective from the date of its issuance and shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

Minister of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزير التجارة والصناعة</orig>
Khalifa Abdullah Al-Ajeel <orig>خليفة عبدالله العجيل</orig>

Issued on: 8 Muharram 1447 AH
Corresponding to: 3 July 2025 AD

# Ministerial Decision No. (136) of 2025
## Regarding the Addition of Commercial Activities

The Minister of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزير التجارة والصناعة</orig>,

Having reviewed:
- Decree-Law No. (68) of 1980 promulgating the Commercial Law, and its amending laws,
- Law No. (111) of 2013 regarding Commercial Shop Licenses, and its executive regulations,
- Decree No. (191) of 2015 regarding the Organization of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>,
- Law No. (1) of 2016 regarding the Issuance of the Companies Law, and its amending laws, and its executive regulations and amendments,
- Cabinet Decision No. (285) dated 25/3/2012 regarding the recommendations of the Committee for Unifying Commercial Classifications of Economic Activities in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>,
- Ministerial Decision No. (689) of 2018 regarding the unification of statistical data classification for economic activities in government entities using the United Nations International Standard Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities (ISIC) <orig>التصنيف الدولي الموحد للأنشطة الاقتصادية</orig> according to Revision 4, internationally recommended by the United Nations Statistics Division, and what has been agreed upon within the framework of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون الخليجي</orig> States,
- Administrative Decision No. (461) of 2024 regarding the formation of the Committee for the Classification of Commercial, Professional, and Craft Activities,
- And the minutes of meeting No. (26) of the Committee for the Classification of Commercial, Professional, and Craft Activities, held on 25/12/2024, regarding the addition of new activities,
- And based on what was presented by the Undersecretary of the Ministry,
- And based on the exigencies of public interest.

It is hereby decided
(Article One)
The activities listed in the table annexed to this decision, numbering (2), shall be added to the commercial activities within the limits applicable in the Unified Guide for the Classification of Economic Activities in the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربي</orig> States.
(Article Two)
All officials – each within their jurisdiction – shall implement this decision, which shall be effective from the date of its issuance and published in the Official Gazette.

Minister of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزير التجارة والصناعة</orig>
Khalifa Abdullah Al-Ajeel <orig>خليفة عبدالله العجيل</orig>

Issued on: 8 Muharram 1447 AH
Corresponding to: 3 July 2025 AD

# Public Authority for Manpower <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig>
## Ministerial Decision No. (5) of 2025
### Regarding the Formation of a Temporary Committee to Manage the Kuwaiti Farmers' Union <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي للمزارعين</orig>
First Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Interior, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Public Authority for Manpower <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig>
- Having reviewed Law No. (6) of 2010 regarding work in the private sector and its amendments,
- And Law No. (109) of 2013 establishing the Public Authority for Manpower <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig>,
- And Decree No. (153) of 2022 transferring supervision of the Public Authority for Manpower <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig>,
- And International Convention No. (87) of 1948 concerning Freedom of Association,
- And the Regulations for the Organization of Trade Union Work <orig>لائحة تنظيم العمل النقابي</orig> issued pursuant to Administrative Decision No. (1470) of 2015,
- And Ministerial Decision No. (3) of 2025 regarding the formation of a committee to manage the affairs of the trade union organization in the absence of a board of directors,
- And based on the requirements of the public interest,
- And based on the issuance of final judicial rulings annulling the Board of Directors of the Kuwaiti Farmers' Union <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي للمزارعين</orig>,
Has decided
### Article (1)
A temporary committee shall be formed for a period of one year, renewable only once, consisting of the following gentlemen, to undertake the tasks of managing the affairs of the Kuwaiti Farmers' Union <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي للمزارعين</orig>, pending the holding of new elections in accordance with the provisions of the law and regulating regulations:

2. Mr. Fahad Misfer Jaber Al-Hayyan <orig>فهد مسفر جابر الحيان</orig> - Vice Chairman
3. Mr. Ahmed Nasser Shabib Al-Shabbak <orig>أحمد ناصر شبيب الشباك</orig> - Secretary
4. Mr. Obaid Nasser Abdullah Al-Nafishan <orig>عبيد ناصر عبدالله النفيشان</orig> - Treasurer

### Article (2)
The Committee shall undertake the tasks specified in Article (3) of Ministerial Resolution No. (3) of 2025, and specifically the following:
- Managing urgent administrative and financial matters of the Federation,
- Collecting subscriptions from members,
- Preparing and updating lists of General Assembly members who meet the conditions for membership and voting rights,
- Calling for a General Assembly meeting,
- Supervising nomination and election procedures in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.
### Article (3)
The Committee shall meet upon the invitation of its Chairman or his Deputy. Its meeting shall not be valid unless attended by at least half of the members, in addition to the Chairman or his Deputy. The Committee shall issue its decisions by an absolute majority of the attending members. In case of a tie in votes, the side with the Chairman shall prevail.
### Article (4)
The Committee shall prepare a detailed report on all its activities and present it to the first General Assembly of the Federation for approval, and a copy thereof shall be submitted to the competent Minister.
### Article (5)
This Resolution shall be effective from the date of its issuance and shall be published in the Official Gazette.
First Deputy Prime Minister

It was decided as follows:

### Article One:
The Authority grants preliminary approval to Al-Sharq Financial Brokerage Company <orig>شركة الشرق للوساطة المالية</orig> for licensing the activity of a qualified securities broker registered in the stock exchange.
This approval is valid for a renewable period of six months, starting from 06/07/2025 and ending on 05/01/2026, for the purpose of fulfilling the criteria specified by the Authority.

### Article Two:
The company mentioned in this decision shall be licensed after completing the requirements referred to in the preliminary approval letter issued by the Authority. This shall be done by amending the existing license activity by canceling the activity of "securities broker registered in the stock exchange" and adding the activity of "qualified securities broker registered in the stock exchange," and changing the job title of registered persons from "representative of a securities broker activity registered in the stock exchange" to "representative of a qualified securities broker activity registered in the stock exchange."

### Article Three:
